title: Navigating the Splunk Interface
description: Get comfortable with the Splunk web interface. Learn where to find key features and how to navigate efficiently.
objectives: Navigate the main areas of the Splunk interface
Use the Search & Reporting app effectively
Understand the search bar and time picker
Find and use the field sidebar

sections.title: The Splunk Home Screen
sections.body:
When you first log into Splunk, you'll see the home screen. This is your launching point for everything.

Key Areas

AreaPurpose
Apps Bar (top)Switch between Splunk apps (Search & Reporting, Enterprise Security, etc.)
Splunk Bar (top right)Settings, Messages, Activity, Account menu
Search Bar (center)Quick search—same as going to Search & Reporting
DashboardsShortcuts to your favorite dashboards

For most work, you'll click Search & Reporting to access the full search interface.

sections.title: The Search & Reporting App
sections.body:
This is where you'll spend most of your time. The Search & Reporting app has three main areas:

1. Search Bar (Top)

This is where you type your SPL queries. It includes:

  • Search input: Where you type your search
  • Time picker: Control which time range to search
  • Search button: Run your search (or press Enter)
  • Search mode: Fast, Smart, or Verbose (leave on Smart for now)

2. Results Panel (Center)

After running a search, results appear here. You can view them as:

  • Events: Individual log entries with highlighting
  • Patterns: Automatically discovered patterns in your data
  • Statistics: Table view for aggregated results
  • Visualization: Charts and graphs

3. Field Sidebar (Left)

Shows all fields Splunk found in your results. Click any field to see its values and add it to your search.

sections.title: The Search Bar in Detail
sections.body:
The search bar is your primary tool. Let's understand each component.

Search Input

Type your SPL here. Features include:

  • Auto-complete: Suggests commands and field names as you type
  • Search history: Click the clock icon to see recent searches
  • Syntax highlighting: Commands and pipes are color-coded

Time Picker

Controls which time range to search. Options include:

  • Presets: Last 15 minutes, Last 24 hours, etc.
  • Relative: Custom relative ranges like "Last 2 hours"
  • Real-time: Continuously updating results
  • Date Range: Specific dates and times

Search Mode

  • Fast: Only returns essential fields (fastest)
  • Smart: Balances speed and field extraction (recommended)
  • Verbose: Extracts all possible fields (slowest)

Start with Smart mode until you have specific needs.

sections.title: The Field Sidebar
sections.body:
The field sidebar (left side of results) is incredibly useful for exploring your data.

Field Categories

  • Selected Fields: Fields currently shown in your results (default: host, source, sourcetype)
  • Interesting Fields: Fields that appear in at least 20% of events
  • Other Fields: Click "All Fields" to see every extracted field

Using the Sidebar

Click any field name to see:

  • Top values: Most common values for that field
  • Value count: How many unique values exist
  • Coverage: What percentage of events have this field

Quick Actions

From the field popup, you can:

  • Add to search: Click a value to add field=value to your search
  • Exclude from search: Add field!=value
  • Add to table: Include this field in your selected fields

The sidebar makes exploration fast—you don't need to know field names in advance.

sections.title: Try It: Your First Navigation
sections.body:
Let's practice navigating the interface with a simple exercise.

Steps

  1. Open Search & Reporting from the apps menu
  2. In the search bar, type: index=_internal
  3. Set the time picker to Last 15 minutes
  4. Click the Search button (or press Enter)
  5. Wait for results to appear

Explore the Results

  1. Look at the Events tab—these are individual log entries
  2. Click on the field sidebar to expand it if collapsed
  3. Find the sourcetype field and click it
  4. Notice the top values—these are the types of internal logs
  5. Click one of the values to add it to your search

The _internal index contains Splunk's own logs—it's always available for practice.

sections.title: Results Display Options
sections.body:
After running a search, you have multiple ways to view results.

Events Tab

The default view. Shows:

  • Timestamp for each event
  • The raw event text
  • Extracted fields (expand with arrow)

Use Events view when you want to see the actual log data.

Statistics Tab

Appears when your search produces a table (using commands like stats, table). Shows:

  • Columnar data
  • Sortable by clicking headers
  • Exportable to CSV

Visualization Tab

Appears when your search produces chartable data. Options include:

  • Line charts, bar charts, pie charts
  • Geographic maps
  • Single value displays

Patterns Tab

Automatically finds common patterns in your events. Useful for:

  • Understanding unfamiliar data
  • Finding structure in unstructured logs
  • Discovering event types

sections.title: Saving and Organizing Work
sections.body:
You don't have to retype searches every time. Splunk provides several ways to save your work.

Save As Menu

After running a search, click Save As to create:

  • Report: A saved search you can run again later
  • Dashboard Panel: Add results to a dashboard
  • Alert: Run automatically and notify you when conditions are met

Search History

Click the clock icon in the search bar to see recent searches. You can:

  • Re-run previous searches
  • Copy search text
  • See when searches were run

Jobs

Click Activity > Jobs to see all your recent search jobs. Completed jobs are cached—you can view results again without re-running.

content.summary:
Key Takeaways

  • Search & Reporting is your main workspace
  • The search bar is where you type SPL queries
  • The time picker controls which time range to search—always set it intentionally
  • The field sidebar helps you explore data without knowing field names
  • Events, Statistics, and Visualization tabs show results in different formats
  • Use Save As to save searches for reuse
